column7: Moist woodlands, moist sandy woodlands, upland rocky woodlands, shaded sandstone cliffs, low areas along streams in wooded areas, shaded seeps and springs along hillsides and ravines, and swamps.
column8: Eastern United States and Canada, from Louisiana to Newfoundland, but most concentrated within Appalachia and the Atlantic Northeast.
column16: Thelypteris noveboracensis is a FERN growing to 0.5 m (1ft 8in) by 0.5 m (1ft 8in) at a medium rate.  See above for USDA hardiness. It is hardy to UK zone 3. The flowers are pollinated by Wind.  Suitable for: light (sandy) and medium (loamy) soils. Suitable pH: mildly acid and neutral soils and  can grow in very acid soils. It can grow in full shade (deep woodland) or  semi-shade (light woodland). It prefers  moist or  wet soil.
column17: No synonyms are recorded for this name.
column21: Plants For A Future can not take any responsibility for any adverse effects from the use of plants. Always seek advice from a professional before using a plant medicinally.None known
column23: A medium density groundcover for a shady or semi-shady location especially in acid soil. This fern is a wetland indicator. Woodland garden. Wildlife: Provides shelter for toads.
column25: A perennial fern forming spreading colonies through rhizomes. Prefers dappled sunlight to medium shade, moist to mesic (requiring a moderate amount of moisture) conditions, and loamy, sandy, or rocky soil that is somewhat acidic. This fern should be located in an area that is protected from prevailing winds[1-6]. Soil Description: acid, rich Can survive and outcompete other species in soil pH below 4. For polyculture design as well as the above-ground architecture (form - tree, shrub etc. and size shown above) information on the habit and root pattern is also useful and given here if available. The plant growth habit is a runner spreading indefinitely by rhizomes or stolons [1-2]. The root pattern is rhizomatous with underground stems sending roots and shoots along their length  [1-2].
